Description: Head from a terracotta figure of Aphrodite. A head broken from a figure, probably of Aphrodite. The hair is parted in the centre, with its waves marked simply by grooves; there is a small bun at the back of the head, and a large plain diadem is worn. The back is unworked, except that the bun is applied. A hole has been bored underneath to fix it to a modern stand. Solid; two-piece mould: it is uncertain whether the head was made with the body or was applied. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt with a grey core; traces of a white dressing on the front only, with a little red paint surviving near the left eye.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Near: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. G 86, from Naukratis; Bayer- Niemeier 1988: no. 15, dated first century bc; Perdrizet 1921: no. 28; Pingiatoglou 1993: no. 176 .
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3358)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
